data.description: Andrew Johnson's complex presidency (1865-69) illustrates the Constitution at work following the Civil War. As the President and Congress disagreed on Reconstruction methods, the Constitution served as their guide on balance of powers, vetoes, and impeachment. In the end, it evolved as a living document with pivotal amendments on freedom, citizenship, and voting rights - topics still vital today.
data.directionsInfo: GPS The GPS setting for Andrew Johnson NHS may be listed as 121 Monument Ave, which is the park HQ in the National Cemetery. To arrive at the Visitor Center, use 101 North College Street, Greeneville, TN. Plane The closest airport is the Tri-Cities Regional Airport, 43 miles NE of Greeneville. From the airport, take I-81 South to exit 36 and follow the signs to Greeneville. Car From I-81S take exit 36 to Rt. 172 south to Greeneville. From I-81N take exit 23 to Rt. 11E north to Greeneville.

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours: Generally open daily from 9 am to 4pm 

Winter/Spring Hours: Generally open Wednesday through Sunday from 9 am to 4 pm.

The historic Andrew Johnson Homestead, 209 South Main Street may be open by guided tour at 10:00, 11:00, 2:00 & 3:00, based on staffing. Tours are limited to 10. Tickets are available at the Visitor Center until 15 minutes prior to tour time. Check with Visitor Center desk for availability, as schedule modifications are sometimes necessary.
operatingHours.name: Andrew Johnson National Historic Site

images.caption: Home of the 17th President from 1851-1875

images.caption: The Museum tells the story of a controversial presidency

data.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in East Tennessee, but temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer and Winter ranges can be extreme. The President's Homestead is not climate controlled and may be closed at times during excessive highs or lows in the summer and winter.
data.name: Andrew Johnson

data.description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,190+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.
data.directionsInfo: There are many points of access along the Appalachian Trail, whether it is by car, train, bus or plane. For more detailed directions, please refer to the "Directions" section of our park webpage.

operatingHours.description:
In general, the Appalachian Trail is open year-round. The northern terminus at Mount Katahdin in Maine is within Baxter State Park, which may be closed in winter months, depending on weather conditions. 
Particular sections of the Trail, and less-developed roads accessing the Trail, may be closed temporarily for a number of reasons, but otherwise the trail is open.
operatingHours.name: Appalachian National Scenic Trail

images.title: McAfee Knob
images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

data.weatherInfo: It is your responsibility to be prepared for all weather conditions, including extreme and unexpected weather changes year-round. As the trail runs from Georgia to Maine there will be different weather conditions depending on your location. For weather along specific sections of the trail and at specific shelters, please refer to: http://www.atweather.org/
data.name: Appalachian

data.fullName: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area
data.description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.
data.directionsInfo: Please use the following link to learn more about how to get here from various locations.

images.title: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.altText: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.caption: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall

data.weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
data.name: Big South Fork

data.description: In 1863, Union and Confederate forces fought for control of Chattanooga, known as the "Gateway to the Deep South." The Confederates were victorious at nearby Chickamauga in September. However, renewed fighting in Chattanooga that November provided Union troops victory and control of the city. After the fighting, a Confederate soldier ominously wrote, "This...is the death-knell of the Confederacy."

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees only apply to Point Park, on Lookout Mountain. If you plan to visit Chickamauga Battlefield, parts of Lookout Mountain Battlefield, exclusive of Point Park, Missionary Ridge, Orchard Knob, Signal Point, or Moccasin Bend National Archeological District, entrance to the park areas is FREE.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Annual Entrance Passes to Point Park allow the passholder and three additional adults to enter the park for free.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From I-75, take exit 350 onto Battlefield Parkway (GA HWY 2) and continue to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway and LaFayette Road. Turn left onto LaFayette Road and continue for approximately 1 mile. The visitor center will be on the right. From I-24, take exit 180 onto Rossville Boulevard (US HWY 27). Continue south to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway. Drive through the intersection, continuing on the LaFayette Road. The visitor center will be on the right.

operatingHours.description: All units of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park are open during daylight hours, with the following exceptions: Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center and Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center are currently open 8:30 am to 5 pm, daily. Visitor centers are closed Dec. 25 and Jan. 1. Point Park main entrance opens at 8:30 am, daily. US Hwy 27 Picnic Area, Wilder Brigade Monument, & Signal Mountain restrooms are closed Dec.1 - March 15.
operatingHours.name: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

images.title: Kelley Cabin on Chickamauga Battlefield
images.altText: Kelley Cabin
images.caption: Living Historians are seen in Kelley Field and in the distance at the Kelley Cabin during the 150th anniversary

images.title: Illinois Monument at Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge

images.caption: Silent sentinels stand on the Illinois Monument at the Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge Battlefield

images.title: Cannon on Lookout Mountain

images.caption: As the sun sets on Lookout Mountain, a lone cannon guards the valley below.

images.title: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.altText: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.caption: The graves of fallen soldiers from Chickamauga to present dot the landscape in Chattanooga as Lookout Mountain looms in the background

images.title: Living Historians on Orchard Knob in Chattanooga
images.altText: Living Historians on Orchard Knob
images.caption: Confederate soldiers stand watch from Orchard Knob during the 150th anniversary of the Battles for Chattanooga in 2013.

data.weatherInfo: The climate in northern Georgia is generally temperate. Short, cool winters give relief from hot summers. Most visitors enjoy this area during long, mild fall and spring seasons.
data.name: Chickamauga & Chattanooga

data.description: Cumberland Gap was the first great gateway to the west. Come follow the path of bison, Native Americans, longhunters, and pioneers. Walk where 300,000 people crossed the Appalachians to settle America. Explore 85 miles of trails and 14,000 acres of wilderness. Stand in 3 states at once. Explore a cave, see Hensley Settlement, or camp under the stars. Come find your connection to Cumberland Gap.
data.directionsInfo: By Plane The closest major airport is located in Knoxville, Tennessee approximately 85 miles away. Flights can also be made into Lexington, Kentucky approximately 130 miles away. By Car The park entrance is located on Highway 25E just south of Middlesboro Kentucky.

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day to pedestrian and cyclist, weather permitting. Some services and facilities have separate hours, however; please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Cumberland Gap National Historical Park

images.title: Hensley Settlement
images.altText: Hensley Settlement
images.caption: Weathered log cabins greet visitors to Hensley Settlement

images.title: Mountain View
images.altText: View from the Pinnacle Overlook
images.caption: View from the Pinnacle Overlook

images.title: Pioneers Crossing Creek
images.altText: Pioneers
images.caption: History comes alive

images.title: Hiker in Sand Cave
images.altText: Sand Cave
images.caption: Sand Cave is a massive sandstone rockshelter found in the backcountry

images.title: Gap Cave
images.altText: Cleopatra's Pool in the Gap Cave
images.caption: Cleopatra's Pool is located deep in the Gap Cave

data.weatherInfo: Summers at Cumberland Gap are hot and humid, with temperatures commonly in the mid to upper 90s. Winters are generally mild with rain and some periods of snow January through March. Temperatures usually range in the 30s and 40s. Weather can sometimes be unpredictable, especially at higher elevations.
data.name: Cumberland Gap

data.description: Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant was becoming quite famous as he wrote these words following the surrender of Confederate Fort Donelson on Sunday, February 16, 1862. The Union victory at Fort Donelson elated the North, and stunned the South. Within days of the surrender, Clarksville and Nashville would fall into Union hands. Grant and his troops had created a pathway to victory for the Union.
data.directionsInfo: The main entrance is at 120 Fort Donelson Park Road, in Dover Tennessee. It is advised to start a visitor experience here. Brochures and information are available at this location. Physical address for the park's Fort Heiman unit, in Calloway County, Kentucky: 654 Fort Heiman Road, New Concord, Kentucky. This site is not staffed daily, but exhibits and information are available for visitors.

exceptions.name: Fall Time Change - Spring Time Change
Labor Day to Fall Time Change

operatingHours.description:
Fort Donelson NB Visitor Center is open daily 8:30 am - 4:00 pm CST.
Dover Hotel hours are 8:30 am - 4:00 pm CST daily.

The park is closed Thanksgiving, December 25, and January 1.  Hours change seasonally.

The park tour route is open:
Spring time change to Memorial Day: 8:00 am to 6:00 pm CDT 
Memorial Day to Labor Day: 8:00 am to 8:00 pm CDT
Labor Day to fall time change: 8:00 am to 6:00 pm CST
Fall time change to spring time change: 8:00 am to 4:30 pm CST
operatingHours.name: Fort Donelson National Battlefield

data.weatherInfo: Fort Donelson National Battlefield traditionally experiences mild to moderate winters and hot summers with an average high of 90 degrees in the summer and 40 in winter; average lows in the winter are 30 degrees but single digits are not unusual. Rainfall in the area averages 53 inches a year with an additional 6 inches of ice/snow and violent thunderstorms can take place at any time of year.
data.name: Fort Donelson

data.description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park. Plan your visit today!

emailAddresses.description:
Our information email inbox is monitored but receives a high volume of inquiries.

Each message is read but it may take several weeks to receive an answer and we may not respond to every email. We greatly appreciate your patience and understanding.

data.directionsInfo: Great Smoky Mountains National Park straddles the borders of the states of Tennessee and North Carolina. The three main entrances to the park are in Gatlinburg, TN; Townsend, TN; and Cherokee, NC.

operatingHours.description: Primary roads are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, year-round, weather permitting. This includes Newfound Gap Road (US-441), Little River Road, and Laurel Creek Road. Secondary roads are closed seasonally.
operatingHours.name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park

images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

data.weatherInfo: Elevations in the park range from approximately 875 feet (267 meters) to 6,643 feet (2,025 meters) and the topography can drastically affect local weather. Temperatures can vary by 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit from mountain base to top, and clear skies lower down do not guarantee equally pleasant weather at higher elevations.
data.name: Great Smoky Mountains

data.description: The Manhattan Project is one of the most transformative events of the 20th century. It ushered in the nuclear age with the development of the world’s first atomic bombs. Most of this development took place in three secret communities located in Hanford, WA, Los Alamos, NM and Oak Ridge, TN. Today, you can visit these three sites that make up Manhattan Project National Historical Park.
data.directionsInfo: Manhattan Project National Historical Park is located in three states: New Mexico, Tennessee, and Washington. For more information on accessing each of these three units, visit our Directions & Transportation page.

operatingHours.description:
Access to the Hanford B Reactor is by tour only. Separate tours of the Historic Sites are also offered. 
For more information about tours of the B Reactor, visit http://manhattanprojectbreactor.hanford.gov/. 
For more information about tours of the historic sites, visit http://tours.hanford.gov/HistoricTours/.
operatingHours.name: Hanford Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: While there is currently no public access to the Department of Energy facilities in Los Alamos, walking tours are available in the town of Los Alamos. The Los Alamos Visitor Center is open Friday through Monday, 10 am to 3 pm.
operatingHours.name: Los Alamos Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: The Oak Ridge Visitor Center is located within the Children's Museum of Oak Ridge. Here you are able to speak with National Park Service rangers, watch a short film on the Manhattan Project, and get literature on Manhattan Project-related historic sites throughout Oak Ridge. Visitor Center services are limited on Sundays, but brochures, maps, and site films are available.
operatingHours.name: Oak Ridge Visitor Center

addresses.line1: National Park Service, Manhattan Project National Historical Park
National Park Service, Manhattan Project National Historical Park

images.title: Oppenheimer and Groves at Trinity Test Site
images.altText: Historic photo of two men standing next to a mangled piece of metal equipment in the desert.
images.caption: J. Robert Oppenheimer and Gen. Leslie Groves at the Trinity Test Site.

images.title: Hanford B Reactor
images.altText: Gray factory building like stacked boxes with single taller smokestack beneath cloudy blue skies.
images.caption: The B Reactor, located along the Columbia River in Washington, was the world’s first full scale nuclear reactor.

images.title: Hanford Hike Through Time
images.altText: Uniformed park ranger talks animatedly to visitors on a hillside overlooking a sprawling urban area.
images.caption: A hike with a Hanford park ranger can lead to new insights and perspectives of the local area.

images.title: Los Alamos Slotin Building
images.altText: Two-story white house with two small windows, a single door, and flat roof stands in a gravel lot.
images.caption: Historic structures endure at Los Alamos, preserving the legacies and untold stories of this important chapter in world history.

images.title: Los Alamos Ashley Pond Walk
images.altText: Uniformed park ranger points to distance of fountain and trees as visitors sit enraptured.
images.caption: Park rangers engage visitors in several locations across the Los Alamos area.

images.title: Oak Ridge X-10 Control Panel
images.altText: Wooden chair sits amid light blue paneling covered in dials, meters, screens, and buttons.
images.caption: Many locations at the Oak Ridge site can be accessed through guided tours coordinated by the US Department of Energy.

images.title: Oak Ridge Family Fun
images.altText: Uniformed park ranger stands with youth along path lined with green broadleaved trees.
images.caption: An outing with Oak Ridge park rangers is fun for the whole family.

data.weatherInfo: The Manhattan Project National Historical Park has units in Hanford, WA, Los Alamos, NM, and Oak Ridge, TN. Check local weather conditions at each unit before you visit.
data.name: Manhattan Project

data.description: The Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail is five sections of hiking trail running roughly parallel to the 444-mile long Natchez Trace Parkway scenic motor road. The foot trails total more than 60 miles and offer opportunities to explore wetlands, swamps, hardwood forest, and the history of the area. For What's Open What's Close visit www.nps.gov/natr/planyourvisit/what-is-open-what-is-closed.htm

emailAddresses.description: It is best to call the Natchez Trace Parkway Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417. The visitor center is open 7 days a week during normal business hours. The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, December 25th and January 1st.

data.directionsInfo: Directions to the Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail vary greatly depending on what section you are trying to reach. For specific questions concerning how to get to a certain section or trail head of the National Scenic Trail, please call the Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417.

operatingHours.description: The Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail is open every day during daylight hours. Severe weather resulting in washouts and downed trees can cause temporary trail closures. The trail is located entirely within the property boundaries of the Natchez Trace Parkway and questions about the trail and its condition should be directed to the Parkway's visitor center by calling 1-800-305-7417.
operatingHours.name: Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail

images.title: Potkopinu Section of the Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail
images.altText: Potkopinu Section of the Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail
images.caption: The Potkopinu section, between milepost 17 and 20, follows the historic Old Trace. The "sunken" nature of the trail is due to the footsteps of thousands of travelers between the 1780s and 1820s in the soft loess soil.

images.title: Rocky Springs Section of the Natchez Trace National Scenic Trail
images.altText: A section of the Old Trace at Rocky Springs (MP 52.4-59)
images.caption: A section of the Old Trace at Rocky Springs (MP 52.4-59)

images.title: Yockanookany Section Trail Head at Cypress Swamp
images.altText: A fork in the trail with directional signs
images.caption: Access to the Yockanookany section of the National Scenic Trail at Cypress Swamp (MP 122)

data.weatherInfo: Mississippi, Alabama, and most of Tennessee are classified as humid subtropical climates. The weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Thunderstorms are common in Mississippi, especially in the southern part of the state, and from June through November, the state is occasionally affected by hurricanes moving north from the Gulf of Mexico. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
data.name: Natchez Trace

data.description: The Natchez Trace Parkway is a 444-mile recreational road and scenic drive through three states. It roughly follows the "Old Natchez Trace," a historic travel corridor used by American Indians, "Kaintucks," European settlers, slave traders, soldiers, and future presidents. Today, people can enjoy a scenic drive as well as hiking, biking, horseback riding, and camping along the Parkway.

emailAddresses.description: For the quickest response please call the Parkway Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417 during normal business hours

data.directionsInfo: Directions to the Natchez Trace Parkway vary depending on what part of the tri-state Parkway you are trying to reach. There are more than 50 roads that access the Parkway in Tennessee, Alabama, and Mississippi. For specific questions concerning how to get to a certain portion of the Parkway, please call the Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417.

operatingHours.description: The Natchez Trace Parkway motor road is open all year, day and night. Operating hours for information centers and some locations do vary. Severe weather resulting in washouts and downed trees can cause temporary road closures. Questions about road condition should be directed to the Parkway's visitor center by calling 1-800-305-7417.
operatingHours.name: Natchez Trace

images.title: Natchez Trace Parkway in Early Fall
images.altText: A slightly curvy section of the Natchez Trace Parkway in Early Fall
images.caption: The Natchez Trace Parkway commemorates a historic travel route that helped build the young United States. The Parkway 444 miles, with plenty of stops to allow you to explore some of the history or enjoy the scenery along the way.

images.title: Double Arch Bridge over Birdsong Hollow (milepost 438) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.altText: View of the Double Arch Bridge from Birdsong Hollow
images.caption: The elegant Double Arch Bridge won the Presidential Award for Design Excellence in 1995. It spans Birdsong Hollow and Tennessee Highway 96. To see it from below, take the TN 96 exit and stop at the pulloff before you get to the highway.

images.title: Mount Locust Historic House (milepost 15.5) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.altText: Mount Locust Historic House
images.caption: Mount Locust served as a family home and as a stand, or inn, for Natchez Trace travelers. Built around 1780, the home and grounds are open for visitors during operating hours.

images.title: Old Trace (milepost 221.4) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.altText: A foggy section of the Old Trace in autumn
images.caption: The "Old Trace," the historic trail commemorated by the Natchez Trace Parkway today, still survives in segments. The Old Trace was the main road through the Old Southwest, connecting Natchez to Nashville by going through Chickasaw and Choctaw lands.

data.weatherInfo: Mississippi, Alabama, and most of Tennessee are classified as humid subtropical climates. The weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers. Average high temperatures reach into the high 90's in summer and often heat indices are over 100 degrees F. Winters are mild with daytime temperatures around 50 F but lows below freezing are not uncommon. Thunderstorms are common in the southeast and the southern part of Mississippi is occasionally affected by hurricanes. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
data.name: Natchez Trace

data.description: The Obed Wild and Scenic River looks much the same today as it did when the first white settlers strolled its banks in the late 1700s. While meagerly populated due to poor farming soil, the river was a hospitable fishing and hunting area for trappers and pioneers. Today, the Obed stretches along the Cumberland Plateau and offers visitors a variety of outdoor recreational opportunities.
data.directionsInfo: The Obed Wild & Scenic River Visitor Center is located at 208 North Maiden Street in downtown Wartburg, Tennessee. Please use the link for more information.

operatingHours.description: The park is open every day.
operatingHours.name: The park is open every day.

images.title: Obed WSR in Fall
images.altText: Obed in Fall
images.caption: Obed in Fall

images.title: Nemo at Night
images.altText: A star-filled night sky above the silhouette of a truss-bridge
images.caption: A Star-Filled Night Sky above the Historic Nemo Bridge

data.weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
data.name: Obed

data.description: Stretching 330-miles through four states (Virginia, Tennessee, North and South Carolina) the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail traces the route used by Patriot militia during the pivotal Kings Mountain campaign of 1780. Follow their campaign by utilizing a Commemorative Motor Route along existing state highways marked with the distinctive trail logo, or 80+ miles of walkable trail.
data.directionsInfo: The trail travels over 330 miles through four states.

operatingHours.description:
The Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail can be visited in any season.
It includes sections of walkable pathway, a Commemorative Motor Route, affiliated historic sites and museums, and wayside exhibits.
Along the way it passes through four NPS areas, two National Forests, an Army Corps of Engineers Dam &Reservoir, plus several state and county parks.
operatingHours.name: Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail

images.title: Cherokee Ford Trail in Gaffney, SC
images.altText: A dirt trail winds along in a forest.
images.caption: Hiking sections of the Overmountain Victory Trail is a favorite pastime.

images.title: Sycamore Shoals in Elizabethton, TN
images.altText: A large group of living historians stand in a river and fire muskets, with a cloud of smoke rising.
images.caption: Living historians bring the Overmountain Victory Trail to life.

images.title: Alexander's Ford Trail at Bradley Nature Preserve
images.altText: A cut log is laying over a crevasse on a trail in the woods.
images.caption: Great hiking adventure awaits on sections of the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail.

images.title: Hampton Creek Cove Trail at Yellow Mountain Gap
images.altText: 5 people are hiking along a trail surrounded by mountains and wildflowers and trees.
images.caption: Hikers enjoy exploring sections of the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail.

images.title: Yadkin River Greenway in Wilkesboro, NC

images.caption: Hikers can enjoy walking over many bridges along the trail.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
data.name: Overmountain Victory

data.description: Visit the sites of the most epic struggle in the Western Theater of the Civil War. Nearly 110,000 American troops clashed in a bloody contest that resulted in 23,746 casualties; more casualties than in all of America's previous wars combined. Explore both the Shiloh and Corinth battlefields to discover the impact of this struggle on the soldiers and on the nation.
data.directionsInfo: The park is 110 miles from the Memphis airport and 150 miles from the Nashville airport. From the west (Memphis, Tennessee, area): Take Highway 72 East to Corinth, Mississippi. From the Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center, take Highway 22 North to the Shiloh Battlefield. From the northeast (Nashville, Tennessee, area): Take Interstate 40 West to the Parker's Crossroads Exit. Then take Highway 22 South to Shiloh Battlefield. Continue on Highway 22 South to the Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center.

operatingHours.description:
The park grounds remain open daily from sunrise to sunset. The Shiloh Battlefield visitor center is open from 9:00 am - 5:00 pm daily. The park film, "Shiloh: Fiery Trial" shows on the hour beginning at 9:00 am with the last showing at 4:00 pm.

The Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center is open from 9:00 am - 5:00 pm daily. 

The America's National Parks Store at Shiloh is open from 8:30 am - 5:00 pm daily during the summer season.
operatingHours.name: Shiloh National Military Park

data.weatherInfo: Shiloh National Military Park traditionally experiences mild winters and hot summers with an average high of 90 degrees in the summer and 50 in winter; average lows in the winter are 34 degrees but single digits are not unusual. Rainfall in the area averages 57 inches a year with an additional 2-3 inches of ice/snow and violent thunderstorms can take place at any time of year.
data.name: Shiloh

data.description: The Battle of Stones River began on the last day of 1862 and became one of the bloodiest conflicts of the Civil War. The battle produced important military and political gains for the Union, and it changed forever the people who lived and fought here.
data.directionsInfo: From Interstate 24 - Take Exit 76 and turn left (eastbound) or right (westbound) onto Medical Center Parkway. Turn left onto Thompson Lane. Turn left at the park entrance at 1563 N. Thompson Lane. Follow the tour road to the visitor center. From Interstate 40 - Take Exit 235 onto TN 840. Take Exit 55 onto US 41/TN 70 and follow the signs for Murfreesboro. Turn right onto Thompson Lane at the first traffic light. Turn right at the park entrance at 1563 N. Thompson Lane.

operatingHours.description:
From March 1st through October 31st,the park tour road is open to vehicles from 8 AM to 5 PM daily. Gates to the parking areas at Stones River National Cemetery, McFadden Farm (Tour Stop 6) and Redoubt Brannan are also open from 8 AM to 5 PM. 

WINTER HOURS - From November 1st through the end of February, the gates listed above close at 4:30 PM.

Visitor Center parking open from 7 AM to 30-45 minutes before sunset daily. 

Pedestrians and bicyclists may use park roads and trails from sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Park Tour Road

images.title: Sunrise at Mendenhall's Artillery Trail
images.altText: The sun rises behind a green field with a cannon in the foreground.
images.caption: On January 2, 1863, fifty-seven Union cannons fired from this line ending the Battle of Stones River by killing or wounding more than 1,800 Confederates in less than an hour.

images.title: Stones River National Cemetery
images.altText: A ray of sunlight shines on the ground at Stones River National Cemetery.
images.caption: More than 6,100 Union soldiers lie in Stones River National Cemetery.

images.title: The Chicago Board of Trade Battery
images.altText: Two cannons sit in an icy field.
images.caption: The men of the Chicago Board of Trade Battery got their first taste of combat at the Battle of Stones River and helped stem the Confederate tide from this position during the afternoon of December 31, 1862.

images.title: Union Infantry Program
images.altText: Union soldiers fire muskets.
images.caption: Living history programs help visitors visualize the trials of soldiers during the Battle of Stones River.

images.title: Bike Tour
images.altText: Bicyclists ride down a road bracketed by trees.
images.caption: Thousands of visitors enjoy biking and hiking through the park.

data.weatherInfo: Summer is hot and humid with highs in the 90s. Spring and fall are pleasant. Winter temperatures are variable, but temperatures may drop below freezing with occasional snow.
data.name: Stones River

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears
